The resolution is adopted.
Is anyone surprised that I am somehow deemed unworthy to speak about American foreign policy or that they see me as a
powerful voice that needs to be silenced? Frankly, it is expected because when you
A formal announcement of the House vote tally establishing the procedural legitimacy of the action taken. The precise numerical breakdown, 218 in
favor, 211 opposed and one present, underscores the narrow but decisive nature of the resolution's passage. This moment reflects the constitutional
mechanics of congressional authority where outcomes are determined not by rhetoric but by recorded votes. The declaration that the resolution is
adopted marks a definitive institutional act signaling that the matter has moved beyond debate into enforcement. This
segment frames the gravity of what follows by grounding the controversy in official legislative action rather than speculation.
Thank you, Mr. Speaker. We've heard uh from my colleagues the reasons why uh the representative Omar should be re
removed from this committee. Uh and but I feel like all the reasons have not just yet been stated which is why I rise
to add for the record. Um we've heard about the comments that were made regarding anti-semitism and anti-Israeli views. But I rise to add to the record
that uh as a member of the foreign affairs committee, I've sat there and heard the representative actually spew anti-American rhetoric as well. I've
been in that committee room where the representative equates Israel and the United States to Hamas and the Taliban. Absolutely
unacceptable for a member of that committee. I've also heard the representative quote that it is the United States's fault that there is
turmoil in Venezuela. That is not because of the oppressive socialist and communism that has spread throughout Central and South America in Venezuela
at the hands of the Maduro and Hugo Chavez regimes. That is unacceptable.
Representative Omar's remarks present a personal and philosophical response to her removal, framing the action as an
attempt to silence dissenting voices on American foreign policy. She characterizes herself simultaneously as marginalized and influential, suggesting
that her critics view her as dangerous precisely because of her impact. The metaphor of the wolf and the silent
shepherd introduces a moral narrative in which an action equates to betrayal.
This segment reveals Omar's effort to recast institutional discipline as a broader struggle over conscience, voice, and moral responsibility within
government.
And as a New York representative, to hear the representative belittle to try to diminish the worst of terrorist attack on United States soil in
September 11, 2001 as some people did something that is unacceptable as well.
And I hold the same standard for this side of the aisle that I do the other because when another colleague on my side said something about 911, I also
voted to have her removed from the education committee because I thought that was inappropriate. So, I'm being consistent here and I hope my colleagues
will do the same to show that this is about consistency and accountability because we should not have an individual
with those views on the committee that is tasked with representing our country and our Congress to foreign nations. I yield back.
Representative Nicole Maliotaki's speech constitutes a formal justification for Omar's removal grounded in committee
responsibility. She asserts firsthand experience on the foreign affairs committee, emphasizing that Omar's rhetoric extended beyond controversial
opinions into what she describes as anti-American equivalence by citing specific comparisons Israel and the United States to Hamas and the Taliban.
Maliotakis frames the issue as incompatible with national representation. The speech positions committee membership not as a right but
as a trust requiring alignment with foundational national principles. centuring representative Ilhan Omar of Somali I mean Minnesota whereas elected
members of Congress take an oath to bear true faith and allegiance to the United States without any mental reservation or purpose of evasion whereas
representative Ilhan Omar took an oath of allegiance to the United States upon becoming a citizen declaring I absolutely and entirely renounce and
objure all allegiance and fidelity to any foreign prince potentate state or sovereign of whom or which I have hereto for been
a subject or citizen. Whereas on January 27th, 2024, Representative Omar gave remarks at an event in Minneapolis in
which she made treasonous statements.
Focuses on Maliotaki's critique of Omar's comments regarding Venezuela. She rejects the attribution of Venezuela's
instability to US actions, instead placing responsibility on socialist governance under Hugo Chavez and Nicholas Maduro. The argument is
structured to contrast ideological interpretations of global instability, framing Omar's perspective as dismissive
of authoritarian accountability. Within the context of foreign affairs oversight, this disagreement is presented as disqualifying rather than
merely ideological, reinforcing the claim that Omar's worldview undermines US diplomatic credibility. Whereas Representative Omar said she has spoken
to many Somalians who asked her to intercede for the Somali government by pressuring the United States government into certain actions. Whereas
Representative Omar assured the Somalians she spoke to, "The US government will only do what Somalians in the US tell them to do. They will do
what we want and nothing else. They must follow our orders and that is how we will safeguard the interest of Somalia."
Whereas Representative Omar continued, "For as long as I am in US Congress, Somalia will never be in danger. Its
waters will not be stolen by Ethiopia or others. Sleep in comfort knowing I am here to protect the interest of Somalia from inside the US system."
The speech then addresses Omar's remarks on the September 11th attacks, specifically criticizing the phrasing
that minimized the nature of the event.
Maliotakis emphasizes that clarity in describing terrorism is a moral obligation, not a semantic choice.
Importantly, she asserts consistency by referencing her own vote to discipline a member of her own party for similar
conduct. This segment is designed to preempt accusations of partisan hypocrisy by grounding the action in uniform standards of decorum and respect
for national tragedy. Whereas George Washington warned in his farewell address of 1796 to guard against the impostures of pretended patriotism and
further declared citizens by birth or choice of a common country. That country has a right to concentrate your affections. The name of American which
belongs to you in your national capacity must always exalt the just pride of patriotism more than any appellation derived from local discriminations.
Whereas these statements by Representative Omar clearly violate the oath she took as an elected member of Congress to defend and protect the
United States Constitution. Whereas Representative Omar has exhibited the treasonous tendencies George Washington warned about and her actions must be
condemned by all members of Congress who adhere to the oath they took upon assuming office. And whereas by openly admitting her efforts to advance
Somalia's interest using her position as a United States representative, Representative Omar has revealed herself
to be a foreign agent acting on behalf of a foreign government. Now therefore be it resolved that Representative Ilhan Omar of Minnesota be censured.
Representative Ilhan Omar forth with present herself in the well of the House of Representatives for the pronouncement
of censure. The first censure resolution introduces formal allegations related to Omar's remarks about Somalia. Structured
through traditional whereas clauses, it invokes the oath of allegiance taken by naturalized citizens and elected officials. The resolution alleges that
Omar positioned herself as an advocate for Somali national interests within the US government, framing this as a violation of constitutional duty by
invoking George Washington's farewell address. The resolution situates the accusations within a historical narrative warning against divided loyalty.
Representative Ilhan Omar be centered with the public reading of this resolution by the speaker and representative Ilh Ilhan Omar B and is
hereby removed from the committee of the budget and the committee on education and the workforce.
Mr. Speaker, pursuant to clause 2A1 of rule 9, I rise to give notice of my intent to raise a question of the
privileges of the house. The form of the resolution is as follows. House Resolution 713 censoring Representative Elanomar of Minnesota and removing her
from the Committee on Education and Workforce and the Committee on the Budget. Whereas Charlie Kirk was a lifelong advocate for freedom of speech,
civil political discourse, and the political engagement of youth. Whereas Charlie Kirk was a man of deep faith, a husband, and a father to two young
children. Whereas on September 10th, 2025, Charlie Kirk was assassinated on the campus of Utah Valley University while exercising his First Amendment
right to freedom of speech. Whereas on September 11th, 2025, one day after the assassination of Charlie Kirk, Representative Alan Omar gave an
interview on Zateo's town hall with Medi Hassan in which she smeared Charlie Kirk and implied he was to blame for his own murder.
Moral and rhetorical condemnation to procedural enforcement. The resolution specifies consequences, public censure,
presentation before the House, and removal from committee assignments. The formal tone underscores that the House
is exercising institutional discipline rather than symbolic rebuke. The language reflects Congress's internal mechanisms for maintaining order,
credibility, and accountability among its members, reinforcing the seriousness of the allegations being advanced.
Whereas on September 12th, 2025, two days after the assassination of Charlie Kirk, Representative Alanomar reposted a
video on X, formerly known as Twitter, which disparaged the character of Charlie Kirk and those mourning his death. Whereas the video representative
Alanomar reposted on X, states, "Charlie Kirk is dead, and before the body got cold, the far right propped his corpse
up as a cudgel for their holy war." Whereas the video representative Alan Omar reposted on X further states, "Don't be fooled. These people don't
give a single about Charlie Kirk.
They are just using his death to further their cristofascist agenda. Whereas the video representative Alan Omar reposted on X further states
Charlie Kirk was a reprehensible human being. He enacted his political agenda by praying on weak-minded people. He
took complex socio-economic issues and simplified them by pointing fingers at out groups, demonizing those groups and
sicking his massive following on them. introduces a second resolution tied to Omar's alleged conduct following the death of Charlie Kirk. Regardless of
external factual context, the resolution itself centers on House rules requiring members to behave in ways that uphold
institutional dignity. It argues that public commentary attributed to Omar damaged the credibility of Congress and violated standards of decorum. This
segment reinforces the broader theme running through all original clips that speech by elected officials is subject to institutional limits when it is
deemed to undermine the integrity of the house.
Whereas the video representative repos further states Charlie Kirk was a stochastic terrorist, an adamant trans phobe. He denied the
genocide happening in Palestine. He believed the subjugation of women and in his last dying words he was spewing racist dog whistles. Whereas the video
representative Alan Omar reposted on X further states Charlie Kirk was Dr.
Frankenstein and his monster shot him through the neck. Whereas the video representative Alan Omar reposted on X
further blames Charlie Kirk for his own murder. Whereas clause one of rule 13 of the rules of the house of representatives provides a member
delegate resident commissioner officer or employ employee of the house shall behave at all times in a manner that
shall reflect credibility on the house.
Whereas representative Alanomar's actions in the wake of the assassination of Charlie Kirk are reprehensible and affect the dignity and integrity of
the proceedings of the house and do not reflect the credibility on the house.
Now therefore be it resolved that Representative Elan Omar of Minnesota be censured. Representative Alan Omar forthwith present herself in the well of
the house of representatives for the pronouncement of censure. Representative Alanomar be censured with a public reading of this resolution by the
speaker and representative Alan Omar be and is hereby removed from the committee on education and workforce and removed from
the committee on the budget of the house. As the gavl fell and the vote was tallied, the House officially censured
Ilan Omar, removing her from the Foreign Affairs Committee, the Budget Committee, and the Committee on Education and
Workforce. And for many Americans, this moment was both cathartic and long overdue. Over the years, Omar's record has been marked not just by
controversial statements, but by repeated instances of anti-American, anti-Israel, and unpatriotic rhetoric that went far beyond partisan
disagreements. And today, the country witnessed what real accountability looks like when evidence meets principle.
Congresswoman Nicole Malitaki's meticulously recounted Omar's actions.
From equating the United States and Israel with terrorist organizations like Hamas and the Taliban to blaming America for the humanitarian disasters in
Venezuela under brutal socialist regimes to diminishing the horror of the September 11th attacks with vague and dismissive language. comments that were
not only offensive but incompatible with the responsibility of representing the United States to foreign nations. The removal is more than a procedural
victory. It's a signal that rhetoric has consequences. That the oath to defend the Constitution is taken seriously and
that both parties must be held to the same standards of consistency and integrity as evidenced by Malitaki's citing her vote to remove a Republican
colleague for similarly inappropriate remarks. But the story does not exist in a vacuum. This moment connects to a broader context of accountability in
government. From Senator Josh Holly exposing FBI cover-ups in Biden bribery allegations to Americans demanding transparency from institutions long
shielded by bureaucracy and media silence. For years, voters have watched radicalism and corruption infiltrate our institutions, whether through
ideological extremism, foreign entanglements, or outright obfiscation of the truth. And today's vote was a concrete push back against that erosion.
The censure is not about silencing a voice or attacking diversity. It is about national security, the integrity of Congress, and the fundamental
expectation that elected officials honor their oath and prioritize the interests of the United States above all else. It
is a reminder that public office is a position of immense responsibility, that words have weight, and that the American
people are watching, recording, and judging every action taken on the floor of the House. The removal of Omar is
both symbolic and substantive. symbolic because it demonstrates that even the most prominent figures are accountable
and substantive because it prevents an individual who has repeatedly undermined American values from shaping policy on
committees charged with a nation's budget, education, and foreign affairs.
It is a lesson in transparency and the permanence of recorded evidence showing that tweets, speeches, and public
statements cannot simply be retracted or ignored when they reveal intentions that conflict with constitutional obligations. And perhaps most
importantly, it is a moment of empowerment for citizens who demand that patriotism, truth, and accountability remain at the center of American
governance. A reminder that radical ideologies, no matter how loudly proclaimed, will not go unchecked when they threaten the core principles of the
nation. This vote is a call to vigilance, a demonstration that institutions still function, and a clear message that integrity matters more than
partisan loyalty. As Americans absorb the implications from Omar censure to broader revelations of corruption and
cover-ups, it is evident that the people are no longer passive observers. They are active participants in shaping the
moral and political compass of the country. Today's decision reinforces that accountability is back on the table, that public servants are
answerable to the citizens they represent, and that history will remember both the missteps and the courage to correct them. This is not
just a committee reshuffle. It is a turning point, a testament to the enduring power of truth and a reminder that when the institutions of governance
are confronted with evidence, principle must triumph over politics, and the oath to the United States is absolute for
patriots, for voters, and for anyone who values the integrity of the nation. This is a decisive moment, one that demands
attention, action, and reflection on what it truly means to serve responsibly, honorably, and faithfully in public office. and it sets the stage
for a larger reckoning across Washington that the American people have been waiting for. Beyond the immediate vote, what this moment highlights is the
broader importance of accountability in American governance. Too often, partisan loyalty or ideological convenience allows elected officials to avoid
scrutiny for statements and actions that directly contradict their responsibilities and the oaths they have taken. Ilan Omar's removal from multiple
committees serves as a stark reminder that words matter, that public statements carry consequences, and that positions of power come with an
obligation to uphold the Constitution and represent the nation faithfully. The evidence laid bare, her speeches, interviews, and social media posts
demonstrates a pattern of behavior that compromised national credibility. Yet, it also underscores the power of
documented truth to confront and correct misconduct. The American people now have a clear record of what was said, the
context in which it was said, and the responses it provoked, ensuring that attempts to rewrite history or evade responsibility are no longer possible.
This is more than a single vote. It is a reinforcement of the principle that public service is not a platform for
personal ideology, but a sacred duty to the citizens of the United States and to the principles of liberty, justice, and
national security. Moreover, this censure sends a message beyond just one member of Congress. It sets a precedent
for integrity and vigilance across the halls of government. When public servants are reminded that their actions, rhetoric, and alliances are
scrutinized by both their colleagues and the citizens they serve, it strengthens the foundation of accountability in a
democracy. It also emphasizes that patriotism and principle are not partisan tools. They are non-negotiable responsibilities of anyone entrusted
with public office. From the floor of the House to town halls and social media, Americans are watching how their leaders conduct themselves. And the
expectation is clear. Defend the nation, uphold the law, and act in alignment with the Constitution. The removal of Ilan Omar, therefore, is not just a
moment of political consequence. It is a broader cultural moment that reinforces the idea that elected officials are not
above reproach, that radical or unpatriotic behavior will face consequences and that the American people armed with evidence and engaged
civic participation remain the ultimate arbiters of accountability. For those who have been frustrated by inaction or media silence, today's vote is a
reminder that truth, courage, and principle can prevail even in the most polarized environments. And that when elected officials fail to honor their
oath, corrective measures are both possible and necessary.
